text: Much like objects, query params don’t have an intrinsic sort order. Usually for signature validation a library will first sort the params and then md5/sha1 the resulting params

I am using CRM Extension API but it is sending IO error. I did it by using PHP and it worked well but now I am moving it to NodeJS but now it is sending the IO error. Here is the link for fetching data - <https://34.71.183.92/fetch-data> .. please advice what I'm doing wrong here. <@U2H3TT8F2> <@U7SL518D6>

Is it not possible to update a contacts `Lead Status` property value via the API? I keep getting a 400 response from the "Update a Contact by Email" endpoint when I try to add lead_status as a property in my payload.
Nevermind... user error :sweat_smile:

I have been looking for a way to download a file from an engagement via the API for some time.  It appears that any file uploaded via the “Upload File from your computer” link OR files attached to emails from the conversations inbox, have a property of `hidden: True` in the `/filemanager/api/v2/files/:file_id` endpoint.  I’ve seen a lot of forum chatter about these files not being “publicly accessible” but I find it hard to believe that with metadata attributes like `s3_url` and `cloud_key`  and `alt_key`  that there is no authenticated way to download a file.

Has anyone had any luck with this?
do you have CMS professional?

<@U8G91EPCL> Digging this out of the grave to get some clarification, since my team is having the same issue. Are you saying that it’s currently not possible at all to get a signed-url as an outside developer? aka it is currently impossible for an outside developer to download a file from an Engagement?
Let me verify…

I don’t think so… we have Service Hub professional, Marketing Hub Enterprise, and Sales Hub enterprise.  Does that make a difference in this situation? Is there a solution to be had for CMS professional accounts?
Well, a solution could’ve been to use serverless functions
Interesting. I’ve never read about these before. Reading the examples now

idk, serverless functions sound a lot like using the Automation tab to fire off webhook requests (which we already do).  The problem is that once an “attachment” is in the HubSpot system as `hidden: True`, it doesn’t matter if the Webhook sends us that Engagement object, the file is still not accessible by API.

What kind of form replies it generates and how is generally a point for the consumer of the API meaning the integration vendor, so I think you might have to collect some screenshots demonstrating the issue and send them a tech ticket.
Technically speaking, Semver only requires that you increment the major version when you break something, it doesn't require that you don't increment it, when you don't break something.

Yeah... if you want Signature stuff to work... you have to follow a really specific and ugly RFC...

<https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-cavage-http-signatures-12.txt>

You have to check the internal mapping names for a lot of HubSpot's self-made properties really carefully, because many of them have weird legacy names which don't have anything to do or very little to do with how they appear in the UI.
There have been recent conversations about this in this channel... <@U8G91EPCL> was leading the discussions.

Generally there is some re-factoring of this functionality taking place, but in my own use of HubSpot I am making use of the Hidden files feature but only in a one-way flow, pushing insurance applications and generated documents like quotes, policies, etc. INTO HubSpot, and not trying to get them back out. I am not sure that use case is part of the original design behavior of a hidden file as it currently exists in HubSpot.

<https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/files/post_files>

Files uploaded with the optional parameter hidden set to true will be inaccessible via the file manager or the URLs returned in the response. The hidden parameter is intended for files that are attached to engagements. Changing hidden from false to true will NOT hide existing files.
Thanks <@U012W4YEUTX>! it doesn't seem like the changes made break anything, most jumps in major version look to just add more features which would be a minor increment.
*Can be* a minor increment, even perhaps *should be*. Not *must be*.
That's all I was trying to point out.

FYI, per this dialogue, I reported a 404 in another doc page in this ticket: HubSpot Ticket #3535972 - 404 for an API doc page . But it didn't really end up getting corrected in the way you'd generally expect. <@UFBDBKQ1H> can you have a look and let me know your thoughts?

Totally, I agree it is a guide and not a law. Jumping major versions like this adds friction to upgrading. A major version increase is an upgrade warning for me and sets me up to expect a breaking change.

Hi! Hope everyone's doing well. We're a company that does analysis on HubSpot's CRM data, and we need a way to keep our HubSpot data up to date on a nightly basis, i.e. objects, associated objects, relationships etc. Wondering if anyone found an efficient way in batch syncing all the objects data in the account? Our preliminary approach is to use the search endpoint in each object and filter by `updatedAt` and syncing all the newly updated records every night after an initial full sync
How about using webhooks? Would require some upfront development effort but sounds like a more scalable approach

I’m not sure if you can subscribe to all objects. But if you’re offering this service to multiple clients then you can setup an oAuth application and handle setup with very little configuration once you’ve got it going.

Thanks for the quick reply <@UQERM7BLY> Ya unforuately we cannot subscibe to all objects... Do you have experience with batch syncing all HubSpot data, basically keeping our DB up to date with HubSpot's
FYI: the batch syncing will hit some real issues, logged by other users in recent threads... search for the phrase "race condition" to see why.

Ultimately this all depends on what you need the data for, and how mission critical it is. I imagine it’s just a 1-way export.

In this scenario, it depends on volume. Look at the times your data is most updated and pick a time outside of that window (easy if you have one primary market) and use the API as you’ve been using.

Regardless of what method you’re using, you need to keep in mind the API limits - (<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/usage-details>)

However sensible it sounds to do this on a nightly basis, I would suggest lowering the interval to each hour, maybe even less. Your machines will be busy the whole day pretty much, but you won’t have the problems over a complete overload because you need to handle tons of data at once. In the end the amount of data will be the same, you just spread the load a little.
Following because this is still a live issue for our integrations
Right, that’d be easier if we could rely on a sort order, but I’m following the <https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/faq/v2-request-validation|HubSpot V2 Signature Request validation> documentation
